awd_titl_txt: PFI:BIC - ASPIRE: hierArchical control of a Smart ankle-foot Prosthesis that supports Increased mobility for REal-life activities
awd_abstract_narration:
Locomotion is one of the  most important human functions, serving survival, progress, and interaction. There are 2 million Americans living with an amputation and the majority of those amputations are of the lower limbs. Although current powered prostheses can accommodate walking, and in some cases running, basic functions like walking on various non-rigid or dynamic terrains are requirements that have yet to be met. The goal of this project is to develop and test a smart powered ankle-foot prosthesis that supports increased mobility for real-life activities. This smart service system will be able to identify and adapt to dynamic walking environment. Based on on-board sensing and the activations of the amputee's residual muscles, it will adapt its characteristics to allow for walking among different environments (e.g. concrete, asphalt, grass, gravel, loose sand) providing robust walking and balance to the amputee. The benefits of the acquired scientific and technological understanding from this project can extend beyond prostheses, to machines that interact with humans in cases of assistance and rehabilitation. The partnership's multidisciplinary expertise including engineering design, controls and human factors engineering, provides a unique environment for training of the students involved, and fosters an innovation culture in the next generation of researchers. 

State-of-the-art lower limb prostheses provide reasonable solutions for walking over constant terrain; however, studies show that walking on variable and dynamic terrain may account for a very significant part of real-life functions. The ability to adapt performance at a level of intelligence seen in human walking is necessary to advance the current state-of-the art of lower limb prosthetic devices. This collaborative proposal aims to study the hierarchical processes contributing to the adaptive intelligence inherent in human walking, and to use that knowledge to develop a transformative state-of-the-art ankle-foot prosthesis. By analyzing the anticipatory and reactive mechanisms of the ankle dynamics when stepping on surfaces of different compliance, via the electromyographic signals of the involved lower limb muscles, this research is  expected to enhance the scientific understanding of the control of ankle dynamics. Moreover, by incorporating these principles into the design of a hierarchical controller for a smart ankle-foot prosthesis, this program will enhance the technological understanding of advanced powered ankle-foot prosthesis that enables adaptation to the environment, currently not possible by the state-of-the-art prostheses.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Everyday activities like walking on grass, stepping onto a rug, or transitioning between surfaces of different firmness can pose significant challenges for individuals with lower-limb amputations. Traditional prosthetic devices often lack the adaptability needed to safely and efficiently navigate such environments. To address this issue, we developed and tested a new generation of intelligent, powered ankle-foot prostheses that can adjust to the world around them, enhancing mobility, stability, and quality of life for users.
 
This project aimed to design a prosthetic system capable of understanding and reacting to the changing demands of everyday walking. At its core, the system integrates sensors that detect electrical signals from muscles (EMG), motion data from the joints (kinematics), and forces experienced during walking (kinetics). These signals help the prosthesis “understand” what the user is about to do and adjust its behavior in advance. The result is a highly responsive prosthetic ankle that can adapt in real-time to changing terrain.
 
One of the key achievements of this project was the development of ASTRA-BF, an algorithm that uses machine learning to predict when a person is about to transition from a hard to a soft surface, such as from pavement to grass. The algorithm processes data from EMG and motion sensors and makes predictions 75–150 milliseconds before the foot touches the ground. This foresight gives the prosthetic device time to prepare and adjust, improving both comfort and stability for the user. The system achieved high prediction accuracies in trials, demonstrating its potential to make prostheses more intuitive and safer to use.
 
In addition to algorithm development, the research team created a rich biomechanics dataset by testing healthy individuals walking on a custom-built Variable Stiffness Treadmill (VST 2). This unique treadmill can change how soft or firm the walking surface is, allowing researchers to simulate different real-life conditions in a controlled lab setting. The resulting dataset, now publicly available, includes thousands of gait cycles collected under a wide range of conditions. It is a valuable resource for scientists and engineers developing assistive technologies, rehabilitation tools, and robotic systems.
 
The team also explored new control strategies for prosthetic limbs. One such innovation was an “admittance-based controller” that adjusts the prosthesis’ stiffness based on the terrain. When tested with healthy subjects, this controller improved walking stability on soft surfaces compared to traditional controllers. This kind of adaptability is crucial for reducing the risk of falls, which is a common and dangerous issue for people with limb loss.
 
Beyond technology development, the project had significant educational and societal impacts. Multiple Ph.D., Master’s, and undergraduate students gained hands-on experience in biomedical engineering, robotics, and human-robot interaction. They collaborated closely with an industry partner, SpringActive, to help bring research into practice. The project also led to numerous publications in journals and conferences, and a patent filing on real-time terrain prediction for prosthetic control.
 
In summary, this project made major contributions to the field of rehabilitation robotics and prosthetics. It delivered scientific advances in machine learning, biomechanics, and control theory, all applied to a deeply human problem: helping people walk more naturally and safely. The work sets the foundation for smarter, more intuitive prosthetic devices that can adapt to the real world.


Last Modified: 04/14/2025
Modified by: Panagiotis K Artemiadis
